awd_titl_txt: Community Research and Cognitive Reframing for a Community Retained in Science
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at St. John Fisher College (SJFC). Throughout its five years, this project will fund thirteen scholarships for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in biology or chemistry. This project aims to develop a distinctive model for developing mindfulness and growth mindset in addition to creating meaningful connections between STEM students and their communities. Specifically, in partnership with six Rochester-based organizations, this project will develop SJFC's infrastructure for integrating mindfulness/mindset training, community engagement, and research support within and across STEM programs of study. With over 60% of SJFC alumni employed in the greater Rochester area, this project will strengthen SJFC's capacity to increase the number of diverse, well-qualified STEM graduates who can meet workforce needs and contribute to the economic recovery of the Finger Lakes region.

This project aims to create a supportive community and deliver targeted programming so that at least 85% of the Scholars persist beyond the first year and graduate in STEM within five years. The interventions that will be implemented include mentoring, academic support, cohort-based activities, learning communities, cognitive reframing, career exploration, community-based research, and internships. Scholars will be supported to develop contemplative practices (mindset and mindfulness) that can increase cognitive capacity and release mental anchors (e.g., fixed mindset; stress) that negatively impact learning. The project's research will advance understanding of mindset training, mindfulness pedagogy, and community-based experiences that are designed to create a supportive internal and external community for students. Through dissemination, the project will contribute to the body of research on interventions addressing risk factors for STEM persistence, including Pell and first-generation status, gateway courses, undeveloped STEM identity, and a fixed mindset.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Community Research and Cognitive Reframing for a Community Retained in Science, or 3(CR), a track 1 S-STEM grant awarded to St. John Fisher University, aimed to support academically talented students with significant financial need who chose to major in biology or chemistry. We successfully met all our grant objectives, positively impacting 15 students over the course of the project. One of our key achievements was the retention and graduation rates of our scholars. We are proud to report that 100% of the scholars recruited as first-time first-year students were retained in the sciences into their second year. Furthermore, all scholars who remained eligible for the grant graduated in the sciences within four years. Overall, 87% of the scholars who were supported by the grant graduated in the sciences within four years. Additionally, 92% of the graduated scholars who remained eligible for the grant are now either in graduate school or employed in their field.

The S-STEM program incorporated several key activities designed to support scholars throughout their academic journey. Scholars participated in a series of weekly STEMinars, which included career exploration, professional development, self-reflection opportunities, mindfulness training, and preparation for community engagement. These seminars were crucial in helping students develop a sense of community and resilience. Additionally, scholars received funding for undergraduate research experiences, ranging from paid research opportunities and travel expenses. These experiences provided practical, hands-on learning opportunities that enhanced their academic knowledge and professional skills. 

The intellectual merit of our project is evident in the contributions it made to the knowledge base on STEM success and persistence. We focused on building self-efficacy strategies using a social-emotional approach to support students in high-challenge situations.  This approach increased academic success and a stronger sense of belonging in STEM fields. Scholars participated in PI-created surveys on mindfulness and mindset at the beginning and end of each STEMinar, providing us with both quantitative and qualitative data. We also used vetted tools, such as CLASS-Bio and CLASS-Chem, at the beginning of the fall semesters in their first and fourth years. Our findings have been shared through presentations at national conferences, including the Annual Meeting of the Association of College and University Biology Educators and the AAAS S-STEM Fall Forum. Additionally, we published a book chapter discussing the usefulness of mindfulness-mindset training in developing resilience among undergraduate STEM students.

In terms of broader impacts, our project created a supportive community that significantly enhanced students’ academic persistence, mental health, and sense of belonging. Feedback from scholars indicated that the 3(CR) community successfully provided support throughout their STEM journey and motivated them to accomplish their goals. This highlights the importance of a S-STEM community in fostering academic persistence and a sense of belonging. Scholars reported improved teamwork, confidence, and a better understanding of diversity, equity, and inclusion issues. They also appreciated the cognitive reframing and growth mindset approach, which helped them find value in previously perceived “useless” or difficult classes. This approach encouraged students to acknowledge their struggles and persist, both of which are components of mindfulness. Furthermore, students reported valuable skill development from the program, including improved writing and communication skills, better study habits, and enhanced organization and time management. These skills are crucial for their academic and professional success. Scholars also expressed their professional goals and aspirations, including desires to become leaders in academic, social, and life settings. They emphasized the importance of building confidence, achieving work-life balance, and giving back to the community.

Overall, our S-STEM project has made significant strides in supporting academically talented students with significant financial need to remain in STEM, contributing to their academic success and professional development. By creating a supportive and inclusive community, we have helped these students develop the skills needed to overcome challenges and achieve their goals.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2024
Modified by: Noveera Ahmed
